questions.text: Which of the following statements about the basal ganglia and their associated neurotransmitters is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The caudate nucleus primarily uses acetylcholine as its neurotransmitter.

options.label: B
options.text: The globus pallidus internus (GPi) exerts an excitatory influence on the thalamus.

options.label: C
options.text: The subthalamic nucleus (STN) uses glutamate as its principal neurotransmitter to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi).

options.label: D
options.text: The substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr) inhibits the thalamus using dopamine.

questions.correct_answer: C. The subthalamic nucleus (STN) uses glutamate as its principal neurotransmitter to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi).

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the effect of each basal ganglia pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: B
options.text: The indirect pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: C
options.text: The direct pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: D
options.text: The indirect pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.

questions.correct_answer: A. The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.
questions.explanation:
Direct Pathway

Indirect Pathway

Function

Facilitates motor activity

Suppresses motor activity

Input

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Target

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum Output

Inhibits internal segment of globus pallidus (GPi)

Inhibits external segment of globus pallidus (GPe)

GPi/SNr Effect

Reduced inhibition of thalamus

Increased inhibition of thalamus

Thalamus Effect

Increased thalamic activation

Decreased thalamic activation

Motor Cortex Effect

Enhanced motor activity

Reduced motor activity

Subthalamic Nucleus (STN)

Not directly involved

Activated by reduced inhibition from GPe

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with resting tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the past year. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely underlying pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta

options.label: B
options.text: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain

options.label: C
options.text: Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the striatum

options.label: D
options.text: Degeneration of serotonergic neurons in the raphe nuclei

questions.correct_answer: A. Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the cerebellar structure and its nuclei?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior and posterior lobes regulate posture and balance

options.label: B
options.text: Flocculonodular lobe coordinates fine motor skills.

options.label: C
options.text: Dentate nucleus is key in motor planning and execution.

options.label: D
options.text: Granule cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Dentate nucleus is key in motor planning and execution.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the primary function of the mossy fibers in the internal circuitry of the cerebellum?

options.label: A
options.text: Transmit motor commands to the cerebellum

options.label: B
options.text: Provide excitatory input to granule cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Relay sensory information to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

options.label: D
options.text: inhibit the activity of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.correct_answer: B. Provide excitatory input to granule cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the functional divisions of the cerebellum is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The vestibulocerebellum controls balance and eye movements.

options.label: B
options.text: Spinocerebellum coordinates axial and proximal limb movements

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebrocerebellum handles movement planning and programming

options.label: D
options.text: The flocculonodular lobe coordinates fine motor movements.

questions.correct_answer: D. The flocculonodular lobe coordinates fine motor movements.
questions.explanation:
Functional Division

Function

Description

Location

Spinocerebellum

Coordination of axial and proximal limb movements (Option B)

Coordinates and smoothens voluntary movements, particularly those involving the axial body and proximal limbs.

Central portion of the cerebellum

Cerebrocerebellum

Planning and programming of movements (Option C)

Involved in motor planning and timing, especially for complex, precise movements.

Lateral parts of the cerebellar hemispheres

Vestibulocerebellum

Balance and eye movements

(Option A)

Modulates motor commands to maintain posture and balance.

Integrates information from the vestibular system to coordinate head and eye movements.

  

Flocculonodular lobe

 

Flocculonodular Lobe

Balance and eye movements

Part of the vestibulocerebellum, responsible for balance and equilibrium of the body.
Flocculonodular lobe

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with uncoordinated movements and difficulty in performing rapid alternating tasks, speech difficulty, and experiences rapid, tremulous eye movements. Which of the following features is not typically associated with cerebellar disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertonia

options.label: B
options.text: Dysarthria

options.label: C
options.text: Ataxia

options.label: D
options.text: Rebound Phenomenon

questions.explanation:
Hypotonia

Decreased muscle tone, often on the same side as the cerebellar lesion.

Ataxia (Option C)

Uncoordinated movements, often leading to a "drunken" gait.

Dysdiadochokinesia

Inability to perform rapid alternating movements, such as flipping the hands back and forth.

Dysmetria (Past pointing)

Movements that overshoot or undershoot the intended target.

Intention tremor

Tremors occurring when moving toward a target

Dysarthria (Option B)

Jumbled speech due to lack of coordination in the muscles involved in speech

Nystagmus

Rapid, tremulous eye movements

Rebound Phenomenon (Option D)

Limb jerking back after resistance is suddenly removed

Decomposition of movement

Can't move multiple joints simultaneously.

No sensory deficit

Not typically present in cerebellar diseases.

questions.text: Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions: Part of Papez Circuit Function 1) Cingulate Gyrus A) Conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory 2) Parahippocampal Gyrus B) Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing 3) Hippocampus C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain 4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.explanation:
Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the amygdala is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Controls emotions and motivations

options.label: B
options.text: Connected with the prefrontal cortex & hippocampus for emotional memory processing

options.label: C
options.text: Damage can result in a loss of sexual behaviour.

options.label: D
options.text: The prefrontal cortex develops working memory

questions.correct_answer: C. Damage can result in a loss of sexual behaviour.
questions.explanation:
Part of the Amygdala Circuit

Function

Amygdala

Controls emotions and motivations.

Prefrontal Cortex

Responsible for the development of working memory (Option D)

Hippocampus

Converts short-term memory to long-term memory

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. He displays significant behavioral changes including placing non-food objects in his mouth, increased sexual advances towards staff, and appears to have no fear when approached by the medical team. Which of the following brain structures is MOST likely to be damaged in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cerebellum

options.label: B
options.text: Amygdala

options.label: C
options.text: Hippocampus

options.label: D
options.text: Parietal lobe

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei has a function of thermoregulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Medial preoptic nuclei

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral nuclei

options.label: C
options.text: Para-ventricle nuclei

options.label: D
options.text: Arcuate nuclei

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with significant behavioral changes following a traumatic brain injury. He experiences frequent unprovoked outbursts of anger and aggression, triggered by minimal stimuli, along with emotional blunting and decreased pleasure. Based on his presentation, which brain region is MOST likely affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Hippocampus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial forebrain bundle

options.label: C
options.text: Central gray area

options.label: D
options.text: Ventromedial hypothalamus

questions.explanation:
Centres

Location

Function/Response

Primary Reward Centers

Medial forebrain bundle

Lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus

Lateral hypothalamus: Strong stimulation leads to rage; weaker stimulation induces reward

Plays a dual role in both aggressive and rewarding behaviours

Primary Punishment Centers

The central grey area surrounding the aqueduct of Sylvius in the mesencephalon

Elicits potent aversive responses

Primary Rage Centers

The periventricular zone of the hypothalamus

Lateral hypothalamus

Intense stimulation triggers rage responses: Defensive posturing, aggression, autonomic responses like piloerection and pupil dilation

Inhibitory Mechanisms

Ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus

Hippocampi

Anterior limbic cortex: Anterior cingulate gyri and subcallosal gyri

Suppress or inhibit rage responses

Maintain emotional control and regulate aggressive behaviors

questions.text: In a patient experiencing severe hemorrhage resulting in isotonic fluid loss, which of the following accurately describes the role of osmoreceptors and their effect on the thirst mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased blood osmolality stimulates the supra-optic nucleus to secrete ADH

options.label: B
options.text: Angiotensin II indirectly stimulates the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

options.label: C
options.text: Osmoreceptors in the OVLT and MnPO are stimulated by decreased blood osmolality

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulated SFO osmoreceptors increase ANP secretion, which reduces ADH.

questions.correct_answer: B. Angiotensin II indirectly stimulates the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the control of feeding?

options.label: A
options.text: Both orexigenic and anorexigenic signals are present in the pre-ventricular nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: Leptin, Peptide YY and CCK are all orexigenic signals

options.label: C
options.text: POMC Fragmentation produces alpha MSH promotes food intake

options.label: D
options.text: Orexin peptide produced from the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus plays an essential role in regulating sleep

questions.correct_answer: D. Orexin peptide produced from the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus plays an essential role in regulating sleep

questions.text: Which statement best describes the center-surround model of the basal ganglia?

options.label: A
options.text: The direct pathway broadly inhibits motor actions, while the indirect pathway facilitates specific actions.

options.label: B
options.text: The direct pathway facilitates specific motor actions, while the indirect pathway suppresses competing actions.

options.label: C
options.text: The indirect pathway reduces inhibitory output from the GPi, while the direct pathway increases inhibitory output.

options.label: D
options.text: Both pathways uniformly facilitate all motor actions

questions.correct_answer: B. The direct pathway facilitates specific motor actions, while the indirect pathway suppresses competing actions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about climbing and mossy fibers is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Climbing and mossy fibers provide the primary input to the cerebellar cortex

options.label: B
options.text: The Vestibulocerebellar serves as the pathway for climbing fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Mossy fibers are the terminal endings of the olivocerebellar tracts.

options.label: D
options.text: Mossy fibers use aspartate to provide excitatory signals to the Purkinje cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. Climbing and mossy fibers provide the primary input to the cerebellar cortex
questions.explanation:
Source/Tracts

Fiber Type

Neurotransmitter

Function

Olivocerebellar tracts

Climbing Fibers

Aspartate

Proprioceptive input from the entire body

Vestibulocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the labyrinth.

Spinocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the Muscle spindle, the Golgi Tendon Organ.

Cuneocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the Muscle spindle, Golgi Tendon Organ.

Tectocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from visual & auditory.

Pontocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the motor & other parts of the cerebral cortex.
